title: Viking 1
summary: Viking 1 was the first of two spacecraft, along with Viking 2, each consisting of an orbiter and a lander, sent to Mars as part of NASA's Viking program.[3] The lander touched down on Mars on 20 July 1976, the first successful Mars lander in history. Viking 1 operated on Mars 2307 days (over 61‚ÅÑ4 years)[3] or 2245 Martian solar days, the longest Mars surface mission[3] until the record was broken by the Opportunity rover on 19 May 2010.[7]
